Some of the projects announced are crucial components to providing our communities, schools, homes and businesses the flood protection we need and deserve.
https://garretgraves.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/graves-statement-227-million-trickle-2018-federal-flood-funds

I‚Äôm glad to see project announcements, but this process lacks the regional scale, urgency and transparency taxpayers deserve. A good bit of flooding from the May storm is preventable if we allocate the resources to the right projects with a greater sense of urgency.

And money is an important part of the solution, but it doesn‚Äôt do any good sitting in the bank. 

We‚Äôre almost five years past the 2016 Flood, years after we secured the dollars and the money is slowly trickling out on localized projects.
Last week, Ascension, East Baton Rouge, Iberville and Lafourche parishes secured $22,709,500 - a result of these legislative efforts.

This is record funding to complete projects that had been stalled for decades and includes $1.2 billion in additional funding to deliver the best flood protection we‚Äôve ever had.

Together, these projects will reduce flood risk for communities throughout the state.

After the 2016 Flood we secured the $3 billion to tackle flood protection needs revealed by the 2016 flood and other risks. 

Half was secured to clear the backlog of legacy flood projects and half to provide future protection against flood risks in South Louisiana.

The State-run Louisiana Watershed Initiative recently announced a 2nd tranche of projects across Louisiana.

But $3 billion and three years later, South Louisiana should be flooded with protection projects.

Among her accomplishments at the Pentagon, she was responsible for updating Army regulations upon the repeal of ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Ask, Don‚Äôt Tell‚Äù and instrumental in the development of the Army‚Äôs diversity plan.
